template.description: All the flows I created for the lessons, organized in process groups.
template.name: my_master_template

labels.label: - Gets a file - Creates an attribute containing the hash value of the file contents. - Logs the flowfile state. (Logs go into nifi-status.log)

- Reads files from the input directory - If the file name begins with the letter 'a' - file attributes are logged - file is placed in an output directory - else - a new property is added to the flow file indicating that the file does not start with the letter 'a' - file attributes are logged
- Gets input from specified location - Publishes data as Kafka message to specified Kafka broker

- Reads files from the input directory - If the file name begins with the letter 'a' - file is logged - else - a new property is added to the flow file indicating that the file does not start with the letter 'a' - file is logged
- Kafka console producer creates messages - Nifi processor subscribes to the producer - saves messages in file system - (all in separate files with "random string" filenames, annoyingly)

processGroups.comments: Posts a request where the contents are a flowfile? to a "rebound service" which simply returns the content. Logs the response. Just an exercise to set up a PostHTTP processor and setup an SSL Context Service.

processGroups.name: 37-PostHTTP and SSL Context Service Setup

labels.label: Files with the same name added within the same minute will be given identical names. The second file will be added to this backpressure queue as a result of the failure condition (a file with that name already existing).

- Reads files from the input directory - If the file name begins with the letter 'a' - file attributes are logged - file is placed in an output directory - else - a new property is added to the flow file indicating that the file does not start with the letter 'a' - file attributes are logged

The GetFile processor will (by default) also retrieve files from any subdirectories. - Ensure the specified location is a bottom-level directory/not a parent. - Don't put any files you want to keep below the input location.
- Don't specify the parent directory as the input location.

config.comments: Processes files where the filename does not start with the letter 'a'. Creates the FileMatchIssue property populated with a string saying the file does not start with the letter 'a'.

For each input flowfile this will create many output flowfiles. The input flowfile may contain many entries/records and each will be split into its own flowfile.
In this case, the input is a JSON array with ~350 entries per flowfile; so for every 1 input flowfile, 352 output flowfiles are generated.

GBFS (General Bikeshare Feed Specification) is an Open Data(?) standard for bikeshare systems. The example given in the lecture uses the info from a different bikeshare system but most all bikeshares should use this standard, so if the URL used here doesn't work you should be able to find the analagous URL for almost any bikeshare system in almost any city. You may need to update the field names in the next (and following?) processor(s), or maybe not since they should follow the standard.

config.comments: In the example, this should be PutHDFS but I don't have an HDFS instance..
Add 'MergeID' attribute to mark which flowfiles are from the same source after they are split in the next processor.

processGroups.name: 38-ListenHTTP

processGroups.comments: Queries Google on search term 'nifi' and logs response. Response is too long to confirm it got the search term but it is from google so we'll assume it works. (Even a length of 10240 doesn't show search results, there is a ton of HTML crap at the beginning of the response.)

config.comments: The 'Group ID' property groups consumers together, as many consumers can subscribe to a single (or many) producers. They all read from the same source.

processGroups.comments: - Gets a file - Creates an attribute containing the hash value of the contents of the file - Forks - 1) Logs the flowfile (this effectively destroys the file) - 2) Place a copy of the file in an output directory

The GetFile processor will (by default) also retrieve files from any subdirectories. - Ensure the specified location is a bottom-level directory/not a parent. - Don't put any files you want to keep below the input location.
- Don't specify the parent directory as the input location.
